instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2610: What is 820-2610? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ISL6258: What is ISL6258? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2008 through 2009.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.C7771: What is C7771? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2330 and 820-2532 logic boards that often dies and causes PP1V05_S5_MCP or PP1V05_S5 to be 0.331v instead of 1.05v. If heating this cap restores voltage to this rail, replace.
definitions.820-2327: What is 820-2327? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-2330: What is 820-2330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-2390: What is 820-2390? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
No green light with this board.
I have replaced bad <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>

Board looks very nice and clean!

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 8.4V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.41V

<CHIP>ISL6258</CHIP>
14 ACOK 3.2V
2 DCIN 16.5V
3 ACIN 3.95V

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: Did it have a green light before messing with <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>?

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: No, it had not.

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> was 0.3 volt before replace. Now it's 1.1 volt.

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: Usually fried <TRANSISTOR>Q6910</TRANSISTOR> and <CHIP>U6915</CHIP>, happens if you don't line up the magsafe correctly with it out of the case. Check voltage on pin 5 of <CHIP>U6915</CHIP>

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: pin 5 <CHIP>U6915</CHIP> 0volt

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: it boots when battery is plugged in. I have five <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2327</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boards that acts exactly the same way, works with battery but not with charger

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: Pin 5 should have 18V or so. Check pin 2 of <TRANSISTOR>Q6910</TRANSISTOR>, it should be 9-13V. If that is ok, replace <CHIP>U6915</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q6910</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: Having a hard time finding <TRANSISTOR>Q6910</TRANSISTOR>. They can be found on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2390</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. I DonÂ´t have any of these boards. Need to order from ebay and wait 30 days.

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: You can use a NTZD3152 for testing. It's a bit at it's limit as it is rated for 20V.

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
Ok, thanks.
I have a couple <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boards but I don't want to steal anything from them until I tried to fix them.
I will probably spend a lot of time at this place, reading threads and learn troubleshoting

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
Does any of these two components, <TRANSISTOR>Q6910</TRANSISTOR> and <CHIP>U6915</CHIP>, work without the other. It's always a risk when you take anything from a donor board that the component doesn't work. 

Do I get 9-13volt on pin 2 of <TRANSISTOR>Q6910</TRANSISTOR> if <CHIP>U6915</CHIP> is bad?
Do I get 18 volt on pin 5 of <CHIP>U6915</CHIP> if <TRANSISTOR>Q6910</TRANSISTOR> is bad?

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: Replace them together to avoid wasted time. It is <CHIP>U6915</CHIP> that shorts and then kills <TRANSISTOR>Q6910</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
got <CHIP>U6915</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q6910</TRANSISTOR> today. Replaced both but still no green light.
pin 5 <CHIP>U6915</CHIP> 0volt

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: Voltage on <RESISTOR>R6910</RESISTOR>?

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
Pin 1 voltage is changing between 16.71v and 16.85v
Pin 2 voltage is changing between 15.97v and 16.09v
Pin 6 0volt

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: I asked <RESISTOR>R6910</RESISTOR>...

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: sorry, <RESISTOR>R6910</RESISTOR> is 3.24 volt

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: ok, voltage on pin 2 of <TRANSISTOR>Q6910</TRANSISTOR>?

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q6910</TRANSISTOR>
Pin 1 voltage is changing between 16.71v and 16.85v
Pin 2 voltage is changing between 15.97v and 16.09v
Pin 6 0volt

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: Hmm, almost there. What is on pin 6 of <TRANSISTOR>Q6915</TRANSISTOR>, it must be low.

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q6915</TRANSISTOR>
pin 2 3.2 volt
the other pins are 0 volt

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
If pin 6 on <TRANSISTOR>Q6915</TRANSISTOR> is low then pin 2 of <TRANSISTOR>Q6910</TRANSISTOR> should have about 8-9V. Check <RESISTOR>R6911</RESISTOR>/12 and traces. Could also be a dead <TRANSISTOR>Q6910</TRANSISTOR> pulling up the gate. 
Check resistance to GND on pin 6 of <TRANSISTOR>Q6910</TRANSISTOR>, there could be a short that kills <TRANSISTOR>Q6910</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: pin 6 <TRANSISTOR>Q6910</TRANSISTOR> to ground is 114 K

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: So figure out why the gate of <TRANSISTOR>Q6910</TRANSISTOR> is not 9V. I cannot help more here I gave you all the hints.

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: Yes I will try. Thanks for helping me understand how the old onewire works.
